segments.en: Near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove.

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahākassapo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ mahākassapaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
segments.en: Then Venerable Mahākassapa went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:

segments.pli: “jiṇṇosi dāni tvaṃ, kassapa, garukāni ca te imāni sāṇāni paṃsukūlāni nibbasanāni.
segments.en: “You’re old now, Kassapa. Those worn-out hempen rag robes must be a burden for you.

segments.pli: Tasmātiha tvaṃ, kassapa, gahapatāni ceva cīvarāni dhārehi, nimantanāni ca bhuñjāhi, mama ca santike viharāhī”ti.
segments.en: So Kassapa, you should wear clothes given by householders, accept invitations for the meal, and stay in my presence.”

segments.pli: “Ahaṃ kho, bhante, dīgharattaṃ āraññiko ceva āraññikattassa ca vaṇṇavādī, piṇḍapātiko ceva piṇḍapātikattassa ca vaṇṇavādī, paṃsukūliko ceva paṃsukūlikattassa ca vaṇṇavādī, tecīvariko ceva tecīvarikattassa ca vaṇṇavādī, appiccho ceva appicchatāya ca vaṇṇavādī, santuṭṭho ceva santuṭṭhiyā ca vaṇṇavādī, pavivitto ceva pavivekassa ca vaṇṇavādī, asaṃsaṭṭho ceva asaṃsaggassa ca vaṇṇavādī, āraddhavīriyo ceva vīriyārambhassa ca vaṇṇavādī”ti.
segments.en: “For a long time, sir, I’ve lived in the wilderness, eaten only alms-food, worn rag robes, and owned just three robes; and I’ve praised these things. I’ve been one of few wishes, content, secluded, aloof, and energetic; and I’ve praised these things.”

segments.pli: “Kiṃ pana tvaṃ, kassapa, atthavasaṃ sampassamāno dīgharattaṃ āraññiko ceva āraññikattassa ca vaṇṇavādī, piṇḍapātiko ceva … pe …
segments.en: “But seeing what benefit, Kassapa, have you long practiced these things?”

segments.pli: “Dve khvāhaṃ, bhante, atthavase sampassamāno dīgharattaṃ āraññiko ceva āraññikattassa ca vaṇṇavādī, piṇḍapātiko ceva … pe …
segments.en: “Sir, seeing two benefits I have long practiced these things.

segments.pli: Attano ca diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāraṃ sampassamāno, pacchimañca janataṃ anukampamāno:
segments.en: I see a happy life for myself in the present. And I have compassion for future generations, thinking:
‘Hopefully those who come after might follow my example.’

segments.pli: Ye kira te ahesuṃ buddhānubuddhasāvakā te dīgharattaṃ āraññikā ceva ahesuṃ āraññikattassa ca vaṇṇavādino … pe …
segments.en: For they may think: ‘It seems that the awakened disciples of the Buddha for a long time lived in the wilderness, ate only alms-food, wore rag robes, and owned just three robes; and they praised these things. They were of few wishes, content, secluded, aloof, and energetic; and they praised these things.’

segments.pli: āraddhavīriyā ceva ahesuṃ vīriyārambhassa ca vaṇṇavādino’ti.
Te tathattāya paṭipajjissanti, tesaṃ taṃ bhavissati dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya.
segments.en: They’ll practice accordingly, which will be for their lasting welfare and happiness.

segments.pli: Ime khvāhaṃ, bhante, dve atthavase sampassamāno dīgharattaṃ āraññiko ceva āraññikattassa ca vaṇṇavādī, piṇḍapātiko ceva … pe …
segments.en: Seeing these two benefits I have long practiced these things.”

segments.pli: Bahujanahitāya kira tvaṃ, kassapa, paṭipanno bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
segments.en: You’re acting for the welfare and happiness of the people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.

segments.pli: Tasmātiha tvaṃ, kassapa, sāṇāni ceva paṃsukūlāni dhārehi nibbasanāni, piṇḍāya ca carāhi, araññe ca viharāhī”ti.
segments.en: So Kassapa, wear worn-out hempen rag robes, walk for alms, and stay in the wilderness.”

suttaplex.blurb: The Buddha points out that Kassapa has grown old, and urges him to give up his ascetic life and stay in a comfortable monastery.
